section: The Sponsor shall be fully liable for any error of judgment or mistake of law that results in a monetary loss for the trust during the oversight, administration or management of the Trust or the performance of its duties hereunder, even without willful misfeasance, bad faith or gross negligence, or by reason of the reckless disregard of its obligations and duties hereunder.
explanation: This section attempts to define the Sponsor's liability, but it does so in a way that contradicts fundamental legal principles. Holding a party 'fully liable' for any error of judgment or mistake of law, even without willful misfeasance, bad faith, or gross negligence, is an extremely high standard that is unlikely to be enforceable. It essentially eliminates the concept of reasonable care and prudent judgment, which are typically benchmarks in determining liability. This contradiction creates uncertainty and potential unenforceability of the liability clause under general legal standards.

section: This Agreement may be terminated at any time, with the payment of a penalty equal to one year of the average management fees collected over the prior three years, with respect to any series or the Trust, by the Board of Trustees of the Trust, or by the Sponsor, in each case on not less than 60 days' written notice to the other party.
explanation: This termination clause has a structural flaw.  It states that termination can occur 'at any time' *with* a penalty.  The structure itself doesn't introduce a clear contradiction, however a standard reading of contracts is that without a penalty, agreements are not able to be terminated at any time. It implies that termination *without* cause at any time *is* possible, creating confusion and potential disputes about whether the penalty is the exclusive remedy for termination or if other limitations apply.

section: Domini may subcontract for the performance of some or all of Domini's obligations hereunder with any one or more persons without needing approval from the Trustees of the Trust to find the subcontracting party to be qualified to perform the obligations sought to be subcontracted; and provided, further, that Domini shall not be fully responsible to the Trust for the acts and omissions of any subcontractor; but shall only be responsible in cases of gross negligence.
explanation: This clause attempts to limit Domini's liability for subcontractors' actions, stating they are only responsible for 'gross negligence'. However, the phrase 'Domini shall not be fully responsible to the Trust for the acts and omissions of any subcontractor' directly contradicts Section 1, where Domini is responsible for management of all tasks. The wording implies that Domini would be responsible for ALL tasks. This misalignment of terminology creates an in-text contradiction and uncertainty regarding Domini's overall accountability.
